objectives.description: Recognize the importance of planning for retirement early, and how starting young provides enormous advantages through compounding.
Explain key factors in retirement planning: life expectancy, time horizon, inflation, and income needs during retirement years.
Analyze strategies to address potential retirement income shortfalls and manage longevity risk effectively.
Understand how compounding works and develop personal strategies for building retirement savings over time.

terms.definition: How long individuals are expected to live, based on statistical averages, family history, and health factors.
terms.example: A 65-year-old today can expect to live into their mid-80s on average, with many living to 90+

terms.definition: The risk that individuals will live longer than expected and run out of money during retirement.
terms.example: Plan for savings to last 25-30+ years while protecting against outliving your money

terms.definition: The number of years until retirement savings are needed; longer horizons allow for more aggressive investing.
terms.example: A 22-year-old has a 43-year time horizon until age 65 - plenty of time to grow wealth

terms.definition: When retirement savings are insufficient to maintain desired lifestyle; the gap between what you have and what you need.
terms.example: Start early, save consistently, invest wisely, and adjust plans as circumstances change

leftPanel.title: Retirement Is Getting Longer
paragraphs: Life expectancy has increased dramatically over the past century. Today, a 65-year-old can expect to live into their mid-80s, with many living well into their 90s or beyond.
This extended lifespan means retirement savings may need to last 20, 30, or even 40 years‚Äîfar longer than previous generations planned for.

highlightBox.text: � The traditional 10-15 year retirement has evolved into potentially 20-30+ years, requiring substantially more savings.

infoCard.title: Implications of Longer Life:
items: More years to fund with savings
More time for inflation to erode purchasing power
Social Security may not fully support you

leftPanel.title: Compounding: The Snowball Effect
paragraphs: Compounding occurs when your investment returns generate their own returns, creating exponential growth over time.
Morgan invested only $18,000 but ended up with nearly as much as Jordan who invested $70,000. Why? Because Morgan's money had more time to compound.

highlightBox.text: � Starting 9 years earlier with less money nearly matched investing 4x more but starting later. Time beats money!

layoutData.title: Your Money Loses Value Over Time
paragraphs: Inflation represents one of the most significant challenges to retirement planning. Even modest inflation rates can substantially reduce purchasing power over an extended retirement period.
bulletPoints: At 3% inflation: $100 today = $55 purchasing power in 20 years
In 20 years: What costs $100 today will cost about $181
In 30 years: What costs $100 today will cost about $243
Rule of 72: Prices double approximately every 24 years at 3% inflation

keyPoint.text: üí∞ A 25-year retirement means you'll need nearly twice as much income at age 90 as at age 65 just to maintain the same lifestyle!

leftPanel.title: Managing Longevity Risk
paragraphs: One of the greatest risks in retirement is outliving your savings. Several strategies can help address potential income shortfalls:

infoCard.title: Benefits of Delaying Retirement:
items: More years to save and invest
Fewer years to fund in retirement

layoutData.title: The Decisions You Make Today Shape Your Tomorrow
paragraphs: Understanding longevity and retirement planning while you're young gives you the greatest advantage possible: time. The earlier you start, the easier it is to build wealth.
bulletPoints: 40+ years of compounding: Starting at 22 vs 32 can double your retirement savings
Habit formation: Establishing saving habits early makes them automatic
Flexibility: More time allows you to recover from market downturns
Lower required savings: Starting early means smaller monthly contributions
Employer match: Never pass up free money from 401(k) matching
Tax advantages: Roth IRAs provide tax-free growth over decades

leftPanel.title: Planning for YOUR Longevity
paragraphs: Life expectancy varies based on numerous factors. Understanding these can help you make more accurate projections for your retirement planning.
Consider your personal circumstances across these dimensions when developing your retirement strategy.

highlightBox.text: � These factors affect both how long you'll live AND your healthcare costs in retirement‚Äîplan accordingly.

scenario.name: Keisha's Grandmother: Financial Security at 90 in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Keisha's grandmother lived to be 90 years old‚Äîsignificantly longer than the average life expectancy for her generation. Through careful planning and smart investments, she maintained financial security until the end.
